Editor’s choice paper Graphene oxide supported chlorostannate (IV) ionic liquid: Brønsted-Lewis acidic combined catalyst for highly efficient Baeyer-Villiger oxidation in water Chen Xing Rong Tan ⁎ Pengbo Hao Mengqiao Gao Donghong Yin Dulin Yin Key Laboratory of Chemical Biology and Traditional Chinese Medicine Research (Ministry of Education), National & Local Joint Engineering Laboratory for New Petro-chemical Materials and Fine Utilization of Resources, Key Laboratory of the Assembly and Application for Organic Functional Molecules, Hunan Normal University, Changsha, Hunan, 410081, China Key Laboratory of Chemical Biology and Traditional Chinese Medicine Research (Ministry of Education) National & Local Joint Engineering Laboratory for New Petro-chemical Materials and Fine Utilization of Resources Key Laboratory of the Assembly and Application for Organic Functional Molecules Hunan Normal University Changsha Hunan 410081 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Lewis acidic chlorostannate(IV)-based imidazolium ionic liquid ([PmimCl][SnCl4] x IL) was post-grafted on graphene oxide (GO) nanosheets through a silylation process. Characterization results suggested the coexistence of intrinsic carboxylic acid on GO edges and the post-grafted Lewis acidic IL on GO planes in the catalysts. The Brønsted-Lewis acidic combined catalysts of GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] were highly efficient and universal in Baeyer-Villiger (BV) oxidation in water due to the high water-dispersion, diminished diffusion limitation, enriched surface acid sites, as well as the concerted effects between Brønsted and Lewis acid sites. Only 3.0 mol% of GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x (x =0.5, 1.0, 1.5) was sufficient for affording almost quantitative yield of a wide range of lactones in water without the need of any organic solvents and cocatalysts, whereas Lewis acidic IL of [PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 itself was far less efficient. More importantly, the heterogeneous catalysts were perfectly stable and could be reused several times without significant loss of activity and selectivity. Keywords GO Chlorostannate(IV)-based imidazolium IL Brønsted-Lewis acidic combined catalysts BV oxidation Water 1 Introduction BV oxidation, first reported by Baeyer and Villiger in 1899 [1], was one of the most important oxidation reactions in organic chemistry, which provided a simple and efficient approach for converting ketones into valuable lactones or esters with excellent region and stereo-selectivity [2]. This transformation carried through a nucleophilic attack on the carbonyl group of ketone by the oxidant followed by a concerted rearrangement with retention of the configuration at the migrating carbon atom [3]. Organic peroxyacids like m-chloro-perbenzoic acid, peroxybenzoic acid, and trifluoroperacetic acid are commonly used as the efficient oxidants for this transformation [4]. But it involved some disadvantages such as expensive, hazardous and dangerous in transportation and storage, large amounts of the corresponding carboxylic acid was formed as wastes, and reactions proceed in halogenated solvent, using a buffer (sodium phosphate etc.) to avoid transesterification, etc [5]. Aqueous hydrogen peroxide (aq. H2O2) was the alternative oxidant due to its atom economy and environmental benefits. Several catalysts, such as Pt complexes [6], TS-1 [7], and acid zeolites [8], have thus been developed to activate H2O2 by coordinating with metal sites. Unfortunately, the formed metal peroxide also oxidises other functions such as alcohol or olefinic groups that may be present in the reactant molecule, and thus strongly limits the chemoselectivity of these catalysts. 2001, Corma et al. reported a tetravalent tin (SnIV)-containing beta zeolite as a highly active and chemoselective catalyst for B–V oxidation of ketones with H2O2 [9]. The SnIV-containing silica molecular sieve could activate the carbonyl group in preference to H2O2, giving high yield of lactones or esters with excellent selectivity in methyl t-butyl ether or dioxane [9,10]. Although impressive results had been achieved, efficiently performing the SnIV-catalyzed BV oxidation in water was still a challenge, since bulky water negatively impacted Lewis acidity through competitive coordination to Lewis acidic centers [11]. Hydrophobic Lewis acid catalyst, such as chlorostannate(IV)-based imidazolium ILs, would eliminate the undesirable coordination by excluding water from the Lewis acidic centers. But they also suffered from poor efficiency in aqueous reaction due to reduced water-dispersion of active sites and the enhanced diffusion limit [12–17]. Decoration of the hydrophobic Lewis acid IL on a hydrophilic heterogeneous material should be an alternative way to address above problems, wherein hydrophilic carrier rendered the hydrophobic active sites water-dispersive in aqueous system.. Graphene oxide (GO) was a hydrophilic layered material that had recently attracted much attention of scientists all over the world [18]. The unique surface properties (oxygenated functional groups on the basal planes and edges), large surface area (theoretical 2630m2 g−1), layered structure, and easy exfoliation into monolayers under water made GO a suitable building block for transferring hydrophobic chlorostannate(IV)-based imidazolium ILs into water [19–23]. In particular, the oxygen functional groups on GO surface not only acted as the anchoring sites for the chlorostannate(IV)-based imidazolium ILs, but also provided hydrophilic nature to the resulting catalyst [24–26]. With those points in mind, we decided to introduce the chlorostannate(IV)-based imidazolium ILs onto both sides of GO sheets to produce water-dispersible catalysts for aqueous BV oxidation. Imidazolium chloride-containing organosiloxane was chose as a precursor of the chlorostannate(IV)-based imidazolium ILs, since the imidazolium chloride IL moiety could readily combine with TinIV chloride to give desirable chlorostannate(IV)-based imidazolium ILs. In particular, the organosiloxane could selectively react with hydroxyl groups on GO, leaving other surface oxygen functional groups (epoxy and carboxyl groups) free to ensure the water-dispersion of catalyst. We envisioned that the Lewis acidic IL on GO sheets exposed on the surface should be freely accessible in the aqueous catalysis, which may allow the aqueous BV oxidation to be carried under pseudo-homogeneous condition. More importantly, the intact carboxyl groups of GO which presented as carboxylic acids on edges would act as Brønsted acid to assist the Lewis acid in activating the carbonyl group on ketones by protonation [27]. The cooperation of intrinsic carboxylic acids and post-grafted SnIV-based Lewis acids in catalyst would further accelerate the BV oxidation of ketones with H2O2 in water. Herein, 1-propyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride IL–decorated GO, featuring epoxy groups on basal planes and carboxyl groups on the sheet edges, was synthesized through the silylation of 1-trimethoxysilylpropyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride with hydroxyl groups on both sides of GO sheets. Incorporating tin(IV) chloride with the decorated imidazolium-based IL moiety resulted in the coexistence of intrinsic carboxylic acid on the GO edges and the post-grafted Lewis acidic IL on the GO basal surface. The Brønsted-Lewis acidic combined catalysts were robust and selective in BV oxidation of ketones in water using aqueous H2O2 as an oxidant, owing to the cooperative Brønsted-Lewis catalytic effect, the diminished diffusion limit on the two dimensional sheets, as well as the high dispersion of catalyst in water. Interestingly, despite behaving as homogeneous catalyst, the GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x could be quantitatively recovered from the reaction mixture by centrifugation for steady reuse. It thus realized the homogeneous reaction coupled with biphasic separation in aqueous reaction. The advantages opened a new vista for efficient Lewis-acid-catalyzed reactions in water. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and reagents Cyclopentanone and high-purity graphite (99.9999%, 200mesh) were got from Alfa Aesar. 1-Trimethoxysilylpropyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride and 1-propyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride were purchased from China Jie Cheng in Shanghai. 2-Adamantanone was got from TCI. Cyclohexanone, 4-methylcyclohexanone and 4-phenylcyclohexanone were obtained by J&K. 4-Methyl-2-pentanone was obtained by Alladdin. Other commercially available chemicals were laboratory grade reagents from local suppliers. All of the solvents were purified by standard procedures. 2.2 Methods Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were obtained as potassium bromide pellets with a resolution of 4cm−1 and 32 scans in the range 400–4000cm−1 using an AVATAR 370 Thermo Nicolet spectrophotometer. Surface structure of the samples was measured using a SEM (FEI SEM 450, Czech). X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Philips X'PERT-Pro-MPD diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.542Å). A continuous scan mode was used to collect the 2θ from 5° to 80°. X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) data were obtained with an ESCALab220i-XL electron spectrometer from VG Scientific using 300W Al Kα radiation. The base pressure was about 3×10−7 Pa. Tin contents were determined by Flame Aromic Absorption Spectrometric method (Persee TAS 990, China). Samples were calcined at 1000°C, and then dissolved in sulfuric acid and hydrofluoric acid to thoroughly remove silicon in the catalysts. The residue was mixed with sodium carbonate and sodium tetraborate, and then treated with hydrochloric acid. Mixed solution of trioctylphosphine oxide and 4-methyl-2-pentanone was used to extract the Tin species in the presence of potassium iodide. The content of Tin in extraction was measured on Aomic Absorption Spectrometer at the wavelengths of 286.3nm using nitrous oxide-ethylene flame. Thin layer chromatography (TLC) was conducted on glass plates coated with silica gel GF254. The conversion and ee values were measured by a 6890N gas chromatograph (Agilent Co.) equipped with a capillary column (HP19091G-B213, 30m×0.32 mm×0.25μm). 2.3 Preparation of GO GO was prepared from high-purity graphite powder (99.9999%, 200mesh) by a modified Hummers method [28]. Concentrated H2SO4 (23mL) was added to a 250-mL flask filled with graphite (1g) at 0°C (ice bath), followed by the addition of NaNO3 (0.5g). Then solid KMnO4 (3g) was gradually added with stirring while the temperature of the mixture was maintained below 20°C. The mixture was stirred for 2h. After increasing the temperature to 35°C and maintaining the temperature for half an hour, excess deionized water was added to the mixture and the temperature was then increase to 90°C and stirred for 0.5h. Finally 30% H2O2 was added until the color of the mixture changed to brilliant yellow and there was no gas being produced. The product was filtered and washed three times with 5% HCl solution to remove the metal ions and then washed with deionized water to remove the acid. The resulting filter cake was subjected to dialysis for 7days to completely remove metal ions and acids. The obtained product was dried at room temperature under vacuum overnight, giving GO as yellowish-brown powder. FT-IR (KBr): 3187, 3132, 1735, 1621, 1224, 1050 and 581cm−1. 2.4 Preparation of GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] The preparation of GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x (where x is the molar ratio of SnCl4 to PmimCl, x =0.5, 1.0, 1.5) was outlined in Scheme 1 . Dry GO (0.5g) was sonicated in toluene (50mL) for 0.5h to ensure most GO being fully exfoliated. 1-Trimethoxysilylpropyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride (1mmol, 0.219g) was then added into the solution. After refluxing for 24h under N2, the black slurry was centrifugation and washed with anhydrous ethanol. The obtained GO/PmimCl was dried at room temperature overnight under vacuum. FT-IR (KBr): γmax/cm−1 3298, 2919, 2850, 1725, 1560, 1450, 1236, 1203, 1195, 1047, 840, 738, 645, 624. The content of imidazolium IL in GO/PmimCl is ca. 0.64mmolg−1, which was determined according to the content of nitrogen by elemental analyses. The GO/PmimCl sheet (0.4g) was dispersed in dry toluene (50mL) upon ultrasonication for 0.5h. A certain amount of SnCl4·5H2O was then added into the homogeneous suspension. The mixture was stirred at 80°C for 24h under N2, and then cooled to room temperature. Resulting black suspension was separated by centrifugation. The solid residue was then washed with dichloromethane and dried at room temperature overnight under vacuum to afford the GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x as black solid. Different SnCl4·5H2O amount of 0.14mmol (0.049g), 0.28mmol (0.098g), 0.42mmol (0.147g) resulted in the catalysts of GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 0.5 , GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 and GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.5 , respectively. GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 0.5 : FT-IR (KBr): γmax/cm−1 3310, 2918, 2852, 1728, 1560, 1450, 1240, 1203, 1195, 1047, 840, 738, 647, 620, 453; Tin content: 0.39mmolg−1. GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 : FT-IR (KBr): γmax/cm−1 3104, 2920, 2850, 1731, 1556, 1450, 1233, 1200, 1110, 1050, 833, 738, 649, 624, 457; Tin content: 0.66mmolg−1. GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.5 : FT-IR (KBr): γmax/cm−1 3103, 2924, 2850, 1731, 1560, 1454, 1238, 1197, 1099, 1043, 842, 733, 649, 619, 455; Tin content: 0.83mmolg−1. 2.5 Preparation of RGO/[PmimCl][SnCl4]1.0 For comparison, a reduced GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 , where the [PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 was alone on the GO surface, was also prepared as follows. GO/PmimCl (0.5g) was dispersed in deionized water (50mL) upon ultrasonication for 0.5h. The GO/PmimCl suspension was then treated with l-ascorbic acid (5.7mmol, 1.0g) at room temperature for 48h to remove the residual oxygen functional groups (epoxy and carboxyl groups) on GO surface. After being centrifugated, the resulting RGO/PmimCl was washed with deionized water, and then dried at room temperature overnight under vacuum. The content of imidazolium IL in RGO/PmimCl is ca. 0.68mmolg−1 according to nitrogen content by elemental analyses. The RGO/PmimCl (0.4g) was mixed with SnCl4·5H2O (0.28mmol, 0.098g) in dry toluene (100mL). The resulting suspension was stirred at 80°C for 24h under N2. After being centrifugated and washed with dichloromethane, black solid was dried at room temperature under vacuum for 24h to give RGO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 . FT-IR (KBr): γmax/cm−1 2923, 2852, 1561, 1454, 1369, 1246, 1159, 1110, 806, 738, 686, 624, 462; Tin content: 0.70mmolg−1. 2.6 Preparation of [PmimCl][SnCl4]1.0 The other control catalyst of GO-free counterpart (denoted as [PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 ) was also prepared by direct mixing of SnCl4·5H2O (1mmol, 0.351g) with 1-propyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride (1mmol, 0.175g) at 80°C for 24h. FT-IR (KBr): γmax/cm−1 3569, 3153, 3116, 2962, 2930, 2873, 1612, 1567, 1461, 1378, 1337, 1164, 1108, 1024, 944, 835, 748, 649, 623, 449; Tin content: 2.23mmolg−1 (theoretical value: 2.35mmolg−1). 2.7 Catalyst testing Catalyst (3 mol% substrate, based on the Tin content) and ketones (1.0mmol) were mixed in deionized water (1.0mL) under stirring. H2O2 (30wt%, 3.0mmol) was then added dropwise into the mixture at 90°C within 30min. The mixture was vigorously stirred at 90°C. Reaction progress was monitored by GC. After the reaction, catalyst was separated by centrifugation. Dichloromethane (3×1.0mL) was used to extract the lactones/esters from the reaction solution. The combined organic layers were died with anhydrous Na2SO4, and then quantitatively analyzed by a 6890N gas chromatograph (Agilent Co.) equipped with the capillary column (HP19091G-B213, 30m×0.32mm×0.25Lm). The recovered catalyst was washed with dichloromethane repeatedly, and dried at room temperature overnight for reused. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation of GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4]x (x = 0.5, 1.0, 1.5) GO with the unique layered morphology, together with abundant surface oxygen functional groups [29–33], was a desirable support for hydrophobic [PmimCl][SnCl4] ILs and rendered them water-dispersive. Lewis acidic [PmimCl][SnCl4] was thus post-grafted on basal planes of GO sheets through a silylation of IL-containing organosiloxane with hydroxyls of GO surface. Apart from the reactive hydroxyl groups, other surface oxygenated groups were left free. The process thus resulted in the coexistence of intrinsic carboxylic acid on GO edges and the post-grafted Lewis acidic IL on GO planes. We envisioned that the carboxylic acid groups would cooperate with [PmimCl][SnCl4] to activate of ketones, making the GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x a cooperative catalyst in BV oxidation of ketones. Other intact oxygen functional groups on GO sheets, such as epoxy groups, would ensure the water-dispersion of GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x , allowing the aqueous catalytic reactions to be carried out under pseudo-homogeneous reaction conditions. The synthesis route for the GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x was outlined in Scheme 1. At first, 1-trimethoxysilylpropyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride, the PmimCl IL-containing organosiloxane, was anchored on the layered GO sheet through silylation of alkoxy with the surface hydroxyl groups (–OH) on GO basal planes. Combining Tin(IV) chloride with the decorative imidazolium chloride ILs resulted in the Brønsted-Lewis acidic combined catalysts of GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x , where Lewis acidic [PmimCl][SnCl4] x ILs were located on basal plane of GO and Brønsted acidic carbonyl groups at edges. Notably, different molar feed of Tin(IV) chloride to PmimCl IL resulted in the GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x with different chemical composition (Table 1 , entries 1–3), which in turns affected Lewis acidic strength of [PmimCl][SnCl4] x on GO sheets, and consequently affected catalytic activity of GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x in BV oxidation in water. As expected, the GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x can be well dispersed in water to form a stable suspension (Fig. 1 a), although the [PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 was hydrophobic (Fig. 1c). We speculated that the high dispersion may be related to the hydrophilicity of surface oxygen functional groups. Indeed, the oxygen functional groups-free counterpart of RGO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 was almost incompatible with water due to hydrophobic property of the recovered graphite domains of RGO sheets and also their π-π stacking interaction (Fig. 1b) [34]. Hydrophilic oxygen functional groups on GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x surface were thus responsible for the water-dispersion of GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x . High dispersion of GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x in water enabled the heterogeneous catalyst to behave as the pseudo-homogeneous catalyst for aqueous efficient BV oxidation. 3.2 Characterization of samples 3.2.1 XRD XRD patterns were used to study the change in the structure of GO during the post-grafting process. Fig. 2 showed the powder XRD patterns of typical GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x (x =0.5, 1.0, 1.5) and RGO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 , as well as pristine GO for comparison. Obviously, GO sheets display a strong (002) peak centred at 10.14°, suggesting a layered structure with an average interlayer distance of ca. 0.87nm (Fig. 2a). While, the sharp diffraction peak almost completely disappeared in GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 , regardless of the [PmimCl][SnCl4] x loading (Fig. 2c–e). A reasonable explanation for these observations might be that, during the silylation process, the regularly aggregated GO sheets were efficiently exfoliated to a single layer or a few layers, corresponding to the transformation from crystalline state to amorphous state [35]. It was well known that individual GO platelets were interlinked via a network of hydrogen bonds mediated by oxygen-containing functional groups, as well as the van der Waals forces between layers [36,37]. Post-grafting [PmimCl][SnCl4]–containing organosiloxane on GO sheets may weaken the interlinked driving forces between GO layers, enabling facile exfoliation of the layered GO material. The exfoliated structure made all active sites accessible to regents, which thus allowed the heterogeneous GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x catalysts to behave as pseudo-homogeneous catalysts in the reaction. In case of the RGO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 , a broad peak between 17° and 28° (centred at 19.7°) was detected in XRD pattern (Fig. 2b), which was assigned to the characteristic structure of RGO. It was ascribed to the formation of “re-graphitized” carbon regions and disorderly restacking due to the van der Waals interaction and/or the π-π stacking interaction [38,39]. The restacking of nanosheet should restrict the dispersion of RGO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 in water (as shown in Fig. 2b), which was in turn detrimental to the aqueous BV oxidation. 3.2.2 SEM SEM images provided direct information on the morphology of pristine GO, GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 , and RGO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 , as shown in Fig. 3 . The pristine GO showed a typical laminated structure in SEM image (Fig. 3a). Crumpled sheets orderly agglomerated with each other through the interlayer hydrogen bonds and van der Waals forces between GO nanosheets (Fig. 3a and a’) [36,37]. The delaminated layer structure together with wrinkles endowed GO with high surface area, which was crucial for the high loading capacity of GO towards [PmimCl][SnCl4]. Post-grafting the [PmimCl][SnCl4] on GO planes disturbed the interlayer hydrogen bonds and van der Waals forces. Electrostatic repulsion between negatively charged oxygen-containing functional groups was thus dominative on GO sheets [40], which should loosen the laminative matrix. Indeed, a corrugated lamella was obvious in the SEM image of GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 , on which [PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 was covalently anchored (Fig. 3b). The sheeted structure allowed for free accessibility of active [PmimCl][SnCl4] x to substrates, which potentially benefited the catalytic efficiency in aqueous BV oxidation. Upon the reduction with l-ascorbic acid, the residual oxygen-containing functional groups (epoxy and carboxyl groups) were removed from GO sheets, which eliminated their interlayer electrostatic repulsion. The π-electron conjugation within the aromatic system was thus dominant in RGO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 . As a result, crumpled, thin sheets randomly restacked due to the π-π stacking interaction between recovered graphite domains, forming a disordered solid of RGO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 (Fig. 3c). The randomly aggregated morphology was agreement with the deduction from XRD pattern. 3.2.3 FT-IR The anchoring behavior of [PmimCl][SnCl4] x moiety on the GO sheet was investigated by FT-IR analysis in detail. Fig. 4 showed the FT-IR spectra of GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 , RGO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 , as well as the pristine GO sheet for comparison. Obviously, apart from the plane CC stretching vibration at 1610cm−1, pristine GO showed characteristic vibration bands of surface oxygen-containing groups at round 3414, 1725, 1392, and 1060cm−1, which were associated with the stretching vibration modes of OH in carboxyl/hydroxyl groups, CO in carbonyl/carboxyl groups, COH in hydroxyl groups, and COC in epoxy groups, respectively (Fig. 4a) [41–45]. Post-grafting the Lewis acidic [PmimCl][SnCl4] x on GO sheets resulted in the absence of COH stretching vibration band (at 1392cm−1) and the decreased intensity of OH stretching vibration (at 3414cm−1) (Fig. 4b). It could be interpreted as evidence that hydroxyl groups interacted with [PmimCl][SnCl4] x -containing alkoxysilane during the attachment. Actually, the surface hydroxyl groups could readily induce the silylation of alkoxy group in alkoxysilane [46,47]. Indeed, a new strong band at 1106cm−1 associated with the stretching vibrations of Si-OC group was observed in the FT-IR spectrum of GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 (Fig. 4b), suggesting the covalently grafting [PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 on the flat planes of GO sheet through silylation [47]. Additional new characteristic bands at 2918 and 2853cm−1 associated with the alkyl groups, as well as the bands at ca. 1587, 1246, and 620cm−1 associated with the imidazole ring stretching [37], further confirmed the presence of an [PmimCl][SnCl4] x moiety on GO sheet (Fig. 4b). Notably, the attachment of [PmimCl][SnCl4] x didn’t affect other oxygen-containing functional groups of GO sheets. No significant change in the corresponding characteristic bands was observed in the FT-IR spectrum of GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 (Fig. 4b vs. a). The reserved surface oxygen-containing functional groups, namely carboxyl groups, carbonyl groups and epoxy groups, were crucial for the high efficiency of GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 , since they provided hydrophilic nature to the heterogeneous catalyst. More importantly, the intact carboxyl acid groups located on the sheet edges exhibited Brønsted acidity, which made the GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 a Brønsted-Lewis acidic combined catalyst for cooperative catalysis of BV oxidation in water. As expected, the characteristic stretching vibrations of oxygen-containing functional groups were indistinct in the FT-IR spectrum of RGO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 (Fig. 4c vs. b). Lewis acidic IL moiety of [PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 was still preserved on the GO surface in RGO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 , as shown by the characteristic bands associated with SiOC group (at 1106cm−1), alkyl groups (at 2918 and 2853cm−1), and imidazole ring group (at 1587, 1246, and 620cm−1) (Fig. 4c). It made the RGO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 a Lewis acidic catalyst for the BV oxidation in water. 3.2.4 XPS XPS was employed to gain further insights into surface chemical changes associated with the attachment of [PmimCl][SnCl4] x , as shown in Fig. 5 . Obviously, pristine GO exhibited only C1s and O1s peaks in the XPS survey spectrum (Fig. 5a) [43,44]. New additional signals associated with Sn (Sn 3d, 4s, 4p, 4d) [48], Si (Si 2p, 2s) [49], Cl (Cl 2p) [50] and N (N 1s) [51] components appeared in the XPS survey spectrum GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 (Fig. 5a and b), suggesting the presence of [PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 -containing organosiloxane on GO sheets. Furthermore, in contrast with pristine GO, decreased O1s peak with respect to the C1s peak was observed in the XPS survey spectrum of GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 . It was probably due to that a part of oxygen-containing groups on GO nanosheets were inevitably eliminated in the solvothermal process (GO was refluxed in toluene for 48h under N2 for the post-grafting) [45]. High-resolution C1s XPS spectra of GO and GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 further confirmed the surface chemical changes of GO sheets during the post-grafting (Fig. 5c). Four typical peaks associated with CC/CC (284.7eV), COH (285.6eV), COC (286.8eV) and OCO (289.1eV) groups were obvious in the high-resolution C1s XPS spectrum of GO [51]. Deconvolution of the peak area evaluated the relative contents of oxygenated functional groups on GO sheets. It showed that 12% of the carbon atoms were associated with COH, 58.5% associated with COC, and 20.5% associated with OCO on pristine GO. While, the COH peak for GO weakened obviously (from 12% to 0.93%) upon [PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 modification, accompanied by the new formation of signals associated with C-Si (283.5eV) and CN (285.3eV) in the C1s XPS spectrum of the GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 [49,51]. These observations inferred the silylation of [PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 –containing organosiloxane with hydroxyl groups on GO flat planes. The signal of newly formed CO–Si group should be overlapped with that of COC group (at 286.8eV) of GO sheet due to the similar electronic environments for carbon. Curiously, although the signal was coupled with COC and COSi groups, the peak at 286.8eV was slightly decreased as compared with that in high-resolution C1s XPS spectrum of pristine GO. We could thus speculate that some COC groups were removed during the solvothermal process [45]. Notably, the silylation process didn’t affect the carboxyl group on GO edges, as shown by the intact OCO peak at 289.1eV. These facts confirmed that Lewis acidic [PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 was successfully post-grafted on GO nanosheets through hydroxyl group on GO planes, rather than the edged carboxyl group. It was consistent with the synthesis design, as shown in Scheme 1. The XPS survey spectrum of RGO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 was similar to that of GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 (Fig. 5a), except for the significantly reduced O1s peak with respect to the C1s peak. The difference was related to the removal of oxygen-containing functional groups by reduction process. Indeed, the peaks associated with COH, COC, and OCO groups were absent in the high-resolution C1s XPS spectrum of RGO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 . Notably, the COSi peak was obvious in the high-resolution C1s XPS spectrum of RGO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 , which suggested the successful post-grafting of [PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 on GO basal planes through silylation process. Compared with RGO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 , a significant feature observed for GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 was the presence of oxygen-containing functional groups along with the [PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 moiety on GO surface, which positively affected the catalytic performance of catalyst in the BV oxidation in water. 3.2.5 Acidity determination The combination of Lewis acid and Brønsted acid in GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x was confirmed by FT-IR spectroscopy using pyridine as a probe molecule [52,53]. Fig. 6 showed FT-IR spectra of the GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x (x =0.5, 1.0, 1.5) and RGO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 treated with pyridine, as well as the neat pyridine for comparison. Obviously, neat pyridine represented a well resolved single band at 1437cm−1 in the range of 1400–1700cm−1 arising from its ring vibration mode (Fig. 6d). An additional band appeared at around 1540cm−1 and a monotonic blue shift of the ring vibration band (from 1437 to near 1450cm−1) was observed when pyridine was mixed with the GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x (Fig. 6a–c). The newly formed band at 1540cm−1 was related to the formation of pyridinium ions resulting from the presence of Brønsted acidic sites [53]. Indeed, the characteristic band of carboxyl group at 1725cm−1 disappeared in FT-IR spectra of GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x due to the formation of carboxylate with pyridine. The blue shift of the ring vibration band was an indicative of a coordination of pyridine to Lewis acid sites [53]. The observations confirmed the presence of Brønsted acidic and Lewis acidic sites in GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x . This featured structure made GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x the Brønsted-Lewis acidic combined catalysts for BV oxidation in water. Notably, despite blue shift, the wavenumber of the ring vibration band varied with different molar ratio of SnCl4 to PmimCl (x) in catalysts. Highest wavenumber of characteristic band at 1458cm−1 was observed when pyridine was mixed with GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 (Fig. 6b). If SnCl4/PmimCl molar ratio (x) were 0.5 and 1.5, the characteristic band appeared at relatively low wavenumbers (at 1451 and 1453cm−1, respectively) (Fig. 6a and c). Notably, higher wavenumber of the ring vibration band suggested the stronger Lewis acidity of catalyst [52,53]. Therefore, GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 possessed the highest Lewis acidic strength in the GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x . Interestingly, RGO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 treated with pyridine showed a similar FT-IR spectrum to GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 in the range of 1400–1700cm−1, except for the absence of characteristic band associated with pyridinium ions (at 1540cm−1) (Fig. 6e). Same band shift of pyridine from 1437 to 1458cm−1 suggested the similar Lewis acid strength of RGO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 and GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 . The absence of characteristic band at 1540cm−1 inferred the inexistence of Brønsted acidic sites in RGO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 . Indeed, for the RGO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 , the Brønsted acidic carboxyl groups on GO edges were removed along with other surface oxygen functional groups during reduction. Lewis acidic [PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 was left alone on the GO surface, as shown in Scheme 1, making RGO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 a Lewis acidic catalyst for BV oxidation in water. 3.3 Catalytic performances The combination of Lewis acid and Brønsted acid on hydrophilic GO nanosheets turned GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x into the efficient catalysts for BV oxidation of ketones in water. The catalytic performance of GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x in the aqueous BV oxidation of ketones, using H2O2 (30wt.%) as an oxygen source, was summarized in Table 2 . GO-free counterpart of [PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 was also employed for comparison. As expected, the Brønsted-Lewis acidic combined catalysts of GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x , especially, the GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 , was highly efficient in the BV oxidation with H2O2 in water, 3.0 mol% of GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 was sufficient for affording an almost quantitative yield of 2-oxatricyclo [4. 3. 1. 14,8]-undecan-9-one in water within 2h (Table 2, entry 5). In contrast, only 57% yield of 2-oxatricyclo [4. 3. 1. 14,8]-undecan-9-one was obtained over GO-free counterpart of hydrophobic [PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 under identical conditions (Table 2, entry 1 vs. 5). The comparative results suggested the beneficial influence of GO sheets on the catalytic oxidation. Actually, the fascinating GO sheets as support endowed the GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 with salient features as follows: 1) delaminated layer structure: the featured structure favored the free accessibility of ketones to Lewis acidic [PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 because both sides of the nanosheet were accessible, which made the GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 a pseudo-homogeneous catalyst in the aqueous BV oxidation; 2) hydrophilic surface: the abundant oxygenate groups on GO sheets rendered the catalyst water-dispersive due to their hydrophilicity, which made the Lewis acidic IL of [PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 more compatible with ketones and aqueous H2O2 for pseudo-homogeneous catalysis; 3) enriched surface acid sites: the surface hydroxyl group provided multiple anchoring sites for [PmimCl][SnCl4] x , which resulted in high local concentration of Lewis acid sites for efficient aqueous catalysis. For these reasons, it was not surprised that the GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 in water was even more efficient than these reported Sn-containing mesoporous catalysts in organic solvent (Table 2, entries 8 and 9 vs. entry 5) [54]. Especially, Sn/MCM-41 gave only 47% conversion of cyclopentanone with low selectivity (91%) to lactone when BV oxidation was performed in 1,2-dichloroethane (Table 2, entry 8). The results demonstrated the advantages of GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 used for BV oxidation reaction in water. Interestingly, the midway addition of pristine GO (equivalent to the GO amount in GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 ) into the [PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 -mediated BV oxidation system led to increased conversion of 2-adamantanone from 57% to 74% (Table 2, entry 2 vs. 1), whereas pristine GO itself was inactive (Table 2, entry 3). The improved catalytic activity should be attributed to the cooperative catalytic effect of Brønsted acid and Lewis acid in the catalytic system. Being Brønsted acid, the edged carboxyl groups in GO sheets could assist the Lewis acid Sn atom of [PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 to increase the positive charge on the carbon atom of carbonyl group through protonation [27], facilitating the nucleophilic attack on this group by H2O2. Curiously, pristine GO was almost inactive although it contained intrinsic carboxyl groups on the edges. It was probably due either to the poor accessibility of hydryphobic ketone to the hydrophilic GO sheets in aqueous system or to a lower Brønsted acidity which was insufficient for the ketone activation. To further investigate the function of surface oxygen-containing functional groups, the oxygenate group-free counterpart of RGO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 was prepared as a control catalyst by removing surface oxygenate groups on the GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 sheets. Indeed, the RGO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 was far less efficient than GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 in BV oxidation of 2-adamantanone in water, although the Lewis acidic [PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 was extant (Table 2, entry 10 vs. 5). Only 64% yield of 2-oxatricyclo [4. 3. 1. 14,8]- undecan-9-one was obtained when the reaction was performed for 2h (Table 2, entry 10). Poor dispersion of the RGO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 in water, as well as the absence of cooperative Brønsted acid sites of carboxyl groups on GO sheets, should result in the disappointing catalytic efficiency. Remarkable enhancement of reactivity with the employment of GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 was also observed in the case of other ketones either cyclic or acyclic, as shown in Table 2. Obviously, conversion of the ketones over GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 was significantly higher than that over [PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 or RGO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 in corresponding BV oxidations (Table 2, entry 12 vs. entries 11 and 13, entry 15 vs. entries 14 and 16, entry 18 vs. entries 17 and 19, entry 21 vs. entries 20 and 22, entry 24 vs. entries 23 and 25). Besides 2-adamantanone, the other cyclic ketones, such as cyclobutanone, cyclopentanone and cyclohexanone, were also successfully oxidized to corresponding lactone with high efficiency and excellent selectivity over GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 , although longer reaction time (6h) was required for the cyclopentanone and cyclohexanone (Table 2, entries 12, 15, and 18). The reactivity of 4-methylcyclohexanone was slightly less than cyclohexanone in the aqueous BV oxidation (Table 2, entries 21 vs. 18). Furthermore, the oxidation of acyclic ketone, such as 4-methyl-2-pentanone, also occurred smoothly, affording the corresponding ester with excellent selectivity (>99%) (Table 2, entry 24). Furthermore, we noticed that the SnCl4/PmimCl molar ratio (n) in Lewis acidic ILs had a crucial influence on the catalytic activity of GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x . GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 exhibited highest catalytic efficiency, giving almost quantitative yield (95%) of 2-oxatricyclo [4. 3. 1. 14,8]-undecan-9-one within 2h (Table 2, entry 5). Further increasing or reducing the molar ratio of SnCl4 to PmimCl in catalyst led to a decreased activity in the reaction accordingly (Table 2, entries 4, 5, and 7). A reasonable explanation for the different activity might be that various molar ration (n) regulated the Lewis acidic strength of GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 . Since the BV oxidation were promoted by acid catalysis, GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 with the highest Lewis acidic strength should be the most favorable catalyst for this reaction. 3.4 Reusability Despite behaving as the pseudo-homogeneous catalysts, the GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x (x =0.5, 1.0, 1.5) functions as the heterogeneous catalyst. Hot filtration test have been done to confirm the heterogeneous nature of typical GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 catalyst. At 68% conversion, the reaction mixture was filtered with a filter. The hot filtrate was reintroduced into the reactor, along with a portion of H2O2. After 1h, the conversion did not increase over 73% due to the complete removal of catalyst (Table 2, entry 6). The heterogeneous nature made the GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x recoverable from the reaction mixture. After the reaction, the heterogeneous catalysts were quantitatively recovered from reaction mixture by centrifugation. Supernatant was then separated from the lower catalyst by simple decantation. The recovered catalysts were washed with dichloromethane and dried at 40°C overnight for reuse. Dichloromethane was also used to extract the lactones/esters from the supernatant. Notably, the extraction approach was expected in large-scale industrial processes, in which most of lactones or esters can be directly separated from water without using any organic solvent. Fig. 7 showed the results of recovery and reusability of GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x . To our delight, the catalysts could be reused for seven times with no appreciable decrease in catalytic activity and selectivity in aqueous BV oxidation of typical 2-adamantanone with H2O2. The retention of catalytic efficiency suggested the excellent reusability of GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x in BV oxidation in water. Organic deposits, a main reason for poisoning the Tin-containing catalysts [54,55], was avoided because of the free traffic of reactants and products in the layered nanocomposite. The stability was evident by the FT-IR spectra of the typical fresh and recovered GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 (Fig. 4b and b’). Clearly, no significant changes of the spectra took place even after reuse for seven times. Furthermore, leaching of the active [PmimCl][SnCl4] x species, another important cause of catalyst inactivity wasn’t observed during the oxidation, since Tin content of the reused catalyst was almost identical to that of the corresponding fresh one based on chemical analysis. Indeed, no Tin species was detected in the supernatant (less than 2×10−5 ppm by Flame Aromic Absorption spectrometry). The results gave the convincing evidence for the excellent stability and reusability of the designed catalysts based on GO sheets. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we have designed and prepared a new type of Brønsted-Lewis acidic combined catalysts for BV oxidation in water by post-grafting Lewis acidic [PmimCl][SnCl4] x onto basal planes of GO sheets. Layered GO support endowed the catalysts with some distinct characteristics as follows: (a) high dispersion in water due to the hydrophilic nature provided by the surface oxygenated functional groups, b) free accessibility to substrate due to the unique layered structure, c) cooperative Brønsted-Lewis catalytic effect due to the intrinsic carboxylic acids on the GO edges, and d) steady reuse without poisoning and leaching. The salient features resulted in excellent catalytic activity of the catalysts for a wide range of ketones either cyclic or acyclic in the aqueous BV oxidation, and also rendered the catalysts reusable. All these advantages made GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x the promising catalysts for other important acid catalyzed reactions in water without the need for any organic solvent or additional additives. coredata.dc:description: Lewis acidic chlorostannate(IV)-based imidazolium ionic liquid ([PmimCl][SnCl4] x IL) was post-grafted on graphene oxide (GO) nanosheets through a silylation process. Characterization results suggested the coexistence of intrinsic carboxylic acid on GO edges and the post-grafted Lewis acidic IL on GO planes in the catalysts. The Brønsted-Lewis acidic combined catalysts of GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] were highly efficient and universal in Baeyer-Villiger (BV) oxidation in water due to the high water-dispersion, diminished diffusion limitation, enriched surface acid sites, as well as the concerted effects between Brønsted and Lewis acid sites. Only 3.0 mol% of GO/[PmimCl][SnCl4] x (x =0.5, 1.0, 1.5) was sufficient for affording almost quantitative yield of a wide range of lactones in water without the need of any organic solvents and cocatalysts, whereas Lewis acidic IL of [PmimCl][SnCl4] 1.0 itself was far less efficient. More importantly, the heterogeneous catalysts were perfectly stable and could be reused several times without significant loss of activity and selectivity.
coredata.dc:title: Graphene oxide supported chlorostannate (IV) ionic liquid: Brønsted-Lewis acidic combined catalyst for highly efficient Baeyer-Villiger oxidation in water
